instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (No TrackPad)
threads.message:
I purchased this board used off eBay.

L4800 was blistered and smoked hard. I replaced this and cleaned damage around the area and also replaced <CHIP>U4830</CHIP>.
The board still has no trackpad.

5v is present on L4800 and voltages at <CHIP>U4830</CHIP> all appear to be normal.
The 5v makes it all the way up to J4801 and I can't find corrosion damage on anything in this area.
I am a little nervous here because I am thinking the trackpad could of surged the CPU lines. This was a water damaged board.

Thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (No TrackPad)
threads.message:
Did you try known good trackpad board/flex?
Discard this first; probably liquid went on its circuitry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (No TrackPad)
threads.message:
Yes.   I put the board in a known good MacBook.   I keep one of each model around for testing.
no Track pad in known good machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (No TrackPad)
threads.message:
F4800 is OK?
TP/KB not working at boot menu, nor OSX?
Correct <SIGNAL>LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> signal at J4801?
